Award.AwardTitle: Planning Grant: I/UCRC for Excellence in Logistics and Distribution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Wayne State University (WSU) seeks to join the Center for Excellence In Logistics and Distribution (CELDi) that is currently comprised of the University of Arkansas (lead), the University of Missouri at Columbia, Virginia Tech, the University of California at Berkeley, Clemson University, Oklahoma State and Arizona State University.

The intellectual merit of this effort is the innovative applied logistics research solutions for addressing emerging challenges in the automotive, healthcare and defense industries. These projects will provide scientific answers to fundamental problems in the sustainability of logistics operations and their interface with product design decisions impacting automotive and defense industries. Further, the Center projects will lead to the development of novel real-time prediction and optimization models and methodologies for logistics systems in manufacturing and healthcare systems. The Industrial and Systems Engineering (ISE) department and other affiliated WSU faculty are experts in logistics, product development, and healthcare systems engineering with a track record of quality scholarship and numerous past and current NSF, DoT, DoD, and VA projects. Further, faculty has a long history of collaboration and success in conducting interdisciplinary applied research with industry.

The broader impact of the proposed Center on the industry is immediate due to the nature of I/UCRC. In addition, the project results will be disseminated to industry through publications and presentations at practitioner oriented conferences for broader distribution and impact. The proposed site will transform its ISE curriculum by enhancing applications taught in classes as well as industry guest lectures. Given rich ethnic, racial, and gender diversity of the WSU undergraduate and graduate student body, the Center will help attract and retain women and underrepresented minorities by providing applied research experience and opportunities to participate in integrated science, technology and engineering solutions at member companies. The proposed Center site will engage and enable these students to improve their skills by participating in interdisciplinary applied research projects with industry during academic year and summer internships. The proposed site's projects will be included within WSUs outreach efforts to community colleges and K-12.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Planning Grant for an I/UCRC for joining the CELDi (Center for Excellence in Logistics and Distribution) 

WSU has planned to join the existing CELDi I/UCRC as a new site. The objective of this planning grant proposal was to organize a series of recruiting meetings with potential industry members, and developing and agreeing on an initial research agenda to start the center.

To achieve this objective, WSU have formed an internal planning grant research team composed of faculty from the industrial engineering, civil engineering, economics, and business school and developed a marketing and recruitment plan. WSU already had long-lasting research and educational ties with OEMs and Tier-1 suppliers in automotive, defense industry contractors and agencies, primary healthcare service centers in Michigan, and VA. One of the premise of the planning grant was to coalesce the applied research interest these diverse industries together to create synergies and cross-fertilization among them. During this planning grant, WSU has aggressively marketed and pursued recruitment through individual meetings, presentations at workshops and local conferences with the existing industry collaborators as well as through new relations with other companies by reaching out to alumni and advisory board members.

WSU held individual recruitment meetings with each of the potential member companies. The objective of these meetings is to better understand their applied research needs in logistics and distribution, map their needs to WSU’s capabilities while exemplifying the capabilities with successfully completed projects, and, ultimately, develop an informed interest to join CELDi. Given the strengths of the WSU team and the thrust areas of CELDi, majority of our efforts went into aligning the combined capabilities of WSU and CELDi with the needs of individual companies. The three areas explored in this alignment were the need for more agile and resilient logistics and distribution systems and processes (for the automotive industry), the need to ensure economic and environmental sustainability through better integration between logistics and product development decisions through life cycle considerations (automotive and defense industry), and improving quality and efficiency of processes while maintaining and improving quality and access to care (healthcare). WSU team have identified the applied research needs of individual companies across these industries and planned for having a strategic planning meeting to bring the company representatives together to further discuss and explore. The automotive industry representatives expressed concerns regarding the confidentiality of their applied research priorities and that the value of pre-competitive applied research is hard to justify at the times where the industry is still in the recovery mode and funds required to carry pre-competitive research to their own intellectual property were scarce. As a result, bringing them together in a strategic planning meeting proved to be difficult task. Furthermore, the other two major industries, healthcare and defense industries, expressed interest for the potential learning and technology transfer benefits from the automotive industry’s expertise in product development and streamlined and efficient processes. Without full commitment from the automotive industry, the companies from the healthcare and defense industries has lost interest. While these hurdles and industry-specific mistrust and concerns for competitiveness have prevented the successful strategic planning meeting, WSU team’s efforts have identified the potential resolutions to overcome these hurdles and planted the seeds for future collaboration within the automotive industry.
